Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Elana Greenfield in 2007. The accession number associated with this gift is 2007.021.
Historical/Biographical Note
Jerome Greenfield grew up in Seattle, Washington, and served as a pharmacist's mate in the U.S. Navy from 1942 to 1945. He studied at the University of Jerusalem, and saw action in the 1948 war. Greenfield received his B.A. from the New School for Social Research in 1952, and his M.A. from Columbia University in 1953. At the time that Wilhelm Reich vs. the U. S. A (1974) was published, he was teaching in the English department at the State University of New York in New Paltz.
Preferred Citation

Scope and Content Note
This unprocessed collection is made up of the research files that Jerome Greenfield compiled to write the book, Wilhelm Reich vs. the U. S. A (1974) about the prosecution of the famous German-born, and one-time Communist psychiatrist. The collection contains copies of Reich's writings and correspondence relative to his life as a scientist and Communist as well as copies of others' writing on orgonomics and other Reichian concepts. There are also records of Reich's legal battles against the United States Food and Drug Administration as well as materials on his imprisonment, including correspondence from jail with his daughter Eva. Also of note are copies of correspondence between Reich and Albert Einstein and between Reich and Sergei Eisenstein.
Separated Materials
Books were removed and placed into the Library's general collection.
